title: Ticket #6814: Improve JobEventLog (python) API
description:
Josh has found a number of infelicities while working with the JobEventLog in a non-testing capacity.

  • The JobEventLog doesn't close its FDs until it's been garbage-collected. This causes problems on Windows, where the open FDs prevent directory removal. Proposed solution: add a close() method which closes any open FDs and prevents the JobEventLog iterator from returning any events.

  • The JobEventLog should also be an iterable context manager. (Implement __enter__ (sets timeout to 0) and __exit__ (calls close).

  • The JobEvent doesn't provide access to its underlying ClassAd. The goal here is to make attributes discoverable, so maybe the right thing to do is to add the various dictionary methods (maybe not including writes); see how to emulate container types for Python 2.7 and Python 3.7. The advantage of doing this over just exposing the ClassAd would be (a) no copies or no worries about exposing a mutable internal data structure and (b) the job event "ClassAds" really are dictionaries -- they should never contain an ExprTree. See #6820 for the Python 2.7 implementation. Python 3.7 drops the iter*() methods, but changes keys(), values(), and items() to return 'view objects'. Not sure what the idiomatic solution here is.

  • We should implement __str__ and __repr__.

2018-Nov-01 14:21:44 by tlmiller:
I think this list is up-to-date. Let me know, or if I've misrepresented something.

2018-Nov-01 14:32:56 by karpel:
Looks right to me.

A rationale for exposing the entire classad (maybe through a .classad() method?) is that it could help a lot when developing. You grab the classad and can then print it out to look at all the attributes. When you know what you want, you go back to . syntax to extract them efficiently. A significant part of my frustration with figuring out how to use the events is figuring out which names have what information behind them.

2018-Nov-02 14:27:54 by karpel:
TJ asked me to give some thoughts on possible __str__ and __repr__ methods.

__str__ should probably return the message that shows up in the actual event log on disk. If not, there should probably be a event_msg() method that does do that. This would make it easy to use the bindings to stream the event log as-written to somewhere else (stdout is obvious, but maybe over a network to somewhere else).

__repr__ is murkier, but a somewhat-common convention is to return something that looks sort of like a constructor call with keyword arguments. So maybe it would look something like

<SubmitEvent(cluster=1, proc=2, timestamp=1234)>

Different event types could then include different parameters.

Alternatively, all events could just look like

<JobEvent(type=Submit, cluster=1, proc=2, timestamp=1234)>

The main purpose of the __repr__ is for programmers to look at, so I don't think there needs to be a lot of information there - just a little more than the default, which is to show the memory location :)

2018-Nov-07 11:06:52 by tlmiller:
We should also think about dictionary- vs attribute- based accessors. Arguably, the properties we guarantee should be attributes and the ones we don't in the dictionary (and maybe decline to do anything in __setAttr__() for the constants?).

2018-Nov-07 13:13:00 by karpel:
That divide between attributes and other items makes sense to me.

This: 

>>> x = (0, 1, 2)
>>> x[0] = 5
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
TypeError: 'tuple' object does not support item assignment

indicates that the correct thing to do for __setattr__ and __setitem__ is to raise a TypeError, which seems like an odd choice to me, but I guess it's what's done...

I don't see any reason to have any mutable attributes or items visible from Python. People can build a mutable object of their own by getting data from the event if they want, but the event itself should always represent exactly what came out of the log.

2018-Nov-08 14:45:46 by tlmiller:
After talking with TJ and Mat, our plan is to basically deprecate / actually remove the __getattr__ method, make type, cluster, and proc immutable attributes, and implement __getkey__ but not __setkey__, where __getkey__ will throw if asked for a key that doesn't exit, rather than return None.

The TypeError thing seems a little weird to me, but I'll investigate that a little further; I expect that if we just don't define __setkey__, the right thing(s) will happen.
